dialogue: Look at this bar showing 5/5. Why does having all 5 parts equal 1 whole?

options.text: When you have every part, you have 1
Because it's the biggest fraction with 5

correct_answer.context: Having all the parts means having the complete whole, which equals 1

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one whole.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Think about what it means to have all the parts of something.

Let's think about this together. Look at the bar - all 5 parts are shaded. When the numerator and denominator are the same, that means you have every single part. What does having every part of something mean?

Let me walk you through this. The bar shows 5/5 - that's 5 parts out of 5 total parts. When you have all 5 parts, you have the complete whole bar. It doesn't matter that there are 5 parts specifically, or whether 5 is odd or even. What matters is that you have every single part. When you have all the parts of something, you have 1 whole. That's why any fraction where the numerator equals the denominator equals 1 - because having all the parts means having one complete whole.
